title: Identifier
content: On this page Identifier Use these as Properties when using Class:Render

title: value​
content: </> Key.value: any

title: updated​
content: </> Key.updated: Signal Fires automatically when Key.value is changed

title: obj​
content: </> Class.obj: Instance  Returns the Roblox Instance created by Class

title: Render​
content: </> Class:Render( properties: Properties,-- list of properties and identifiers archivable: boolean-- list will not apply to clones if set to false (default is true) ) → Class
type Properties = {[string | Identifier]: any}

title: Clone​
content: </> Class:Clone() → Class

title: Connect​
content: </> Module.Connect: Identifier Bind a function to a Roblox Event Class:Render({ [Module.Connect.." Activated"] = function(self) self.obj:Destroy() -- destroys itself when clicked end })

title: Once​
content: </> Module.Once: Identifier Bind a function that only gets called once, to a Roblox Event Class:Render({ [Module.Connect.." Activated"] = function(self) self.obj:Destroy() -- destroys itself when clicked end })

title: Merge​
content: </> Module.Merge: Identifier Add a list of Properties to Class local properties = { Name = "ScreenGui" Parent = StarterGui, } Class:Render({ [Module.Merge] = properties })

title: Children​
content: </> Module.Children: Identifier Create/Add children inside of Class Class:Render({ [Module.Children] = { -- Create 3 TextLabels inside Class Module.new("TextLabel"):Render({}), Module.new("TextLabel"):Render({}), Module.new("TextLabel"):Render({}), } })

title: Init​
content: </> Module.Init: Identifier Bind a function that gets called once Class:Render is finished Class:Render({ Parent = StarterGui, [Module.Init] = function(self) print(self.Parent) -- StarterGui end })

title: Reference​
content: </> Module.Reference: Identifier Set Class to a Key's value local ref = Module.key() Class:Render({ Name = "TestClass", [Module.Reference] = ref, }) print(ref.value) -- TestClass

title: key​
content: </> Module.key( v: any-- default value ) → Key Creates a Key local text = Module.key("Testing") local class = Class:Render({ Name = text, [Module.Init] = function(self) print(self.Name) -- Testing end }) text.value = "MyClass" print(class.Name) -- MyClass

title: new​
content: </> Module.new(className: string) → Class

title: SignalConnection​
content: </> interface SignalConnection { Connected: boolean Disconnect: (SignalConnection) → () } Represents a connection to a signal. local connection = signal:Connect(function() end) print(connection.Connected) --> true connection:Disconnect() print(connection.Connected) --> false

title: ConnectionFn​
content: </> type ConnectionFn = (...any) → () A function connected to a signal.

title: new​
content: </> Signal.new() → Signal Constructs a new Signal

title: Wrap​
content: </> Signal.Wrap( rbxScriptSignal: RBXScriptSignal -- Existing RBXScriptSignal to wrap ) → Signal Constructs a new Signal that wraps around an RBXScriptSignal. For example: local signal = Signal.Wrap(workspace.ChildAdded) signal:Connect(function(part) print(part.Name .. " added") end) Instance.new("Part").Parent = workspace

title: Is​
content: </> Signal.Is( obj: any-- Object to check ) → boolean-- true if the object is a Signal. Checks if the given object is a Signal.

title: Connect​
content: </> Signal:Connect(fn: ConnectionFn) → SignalConnection Connects a function to the signal, which will be called anytime the signal is fired. signal:Connect(function(msg, num) print(msg, num) end) signal:Fire("Hello", 25)

title: Once​
content: </> Signal:Once(fn: ConnectionFn) → SignalConnection Connects a function to the signal, which will be called the next time the signal fires. Once the connection is triggered, it will disconnect itself. signal:Once(function(msg, num) print(msg, num) end) signal:Fire("Hello", 25) signal:Fire("This message will not go through", 10)

title: DisconnectAll​
content: </> Signal:DisconnectAll() → () Disconnects all connections from the signal. signal:DisconnectAll()

title: Fire​
content: </> Signal:Fire(...: any) → () Fire the signal, which will call all of the connected functions with the given arguments. signal:Fire("Hello") -- Any number of arguments can be fired: signal:Fire("Hello", 32, {Test = "Test"}, true)

title: FireDeferred​
content: </> Signal:FireDeferred(...: any) → () Same as Fire, but uses task.defer internally & doesn't take advantage of thread reuse. signal:FireDeferred("Hello")

title: Wait​
content: This is a yielding function. When called, it will pause the Lua thread that called the function until a result is ready to be returned, without interrupting other scripts. Yields </> Signal:Wait() → ...any Yields the current thread until the signal is fired, and returns the arguments fired from the signal. Yielding the current thread is not always desirable. If the desire is to only capture the next event fired, using Once might be a better solution. task.spawn(function() local msg, num = signal:Wait() print(msg, num) --> "Hello", 32 end) signal:Fire("Hello", 32)

title: Destroy​
content: </> Signal:Destroy() → () Cleans up the signal. Technically, this is only necessary if the signal is created usingSignal.Wrap. Connections should be properly GC'd once the signal is no longer referenced anywhere. However, it is still good practice to include ways to strictly clean up resources. Calling Destroy on a signal will also disconnect all connections immediately. signal:Destroy()

title: ConnectOnce​
content: deprecated in v1.3.0 </> This was deprecated in v1.3.0 Use `Signal:Once` instead. Signal:ConnectOnce(fn: ConnectionFn) → SignalConnection
